Rationale
Removed Rob Beynon from teaching staff, as per his request.
Blurb
Overview
This module will continue, extend, and broaden the transferable skills developed in Year 1. It will focus on improving the students’ analytical, communication, quantitative, and employability skills. The communication skills component is assessed through a portfolio whereas the quantitative skills component is assessed through a group poster and SAQ.
Educational Aims
Enhance the development of the essential life science skills that students will require to improve their study skills;

Enable students to analyse and interpret scientific data and communicate results; ​

Enhance the employability prospects of students and career awareness. ​
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will continue, extend, and broaden the transferable skills developed in Year 1. It will focus on improving the students’ analytical, communication, quantitative, and employability skills. The communication skills component is assessed through a portfolio whereas the quantitative skills component is assessed through a group poster and SAQ.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus will focus on the development of a number of skills that will support students’ learning throughout their BSc or MBiolSci programme, and will contribute to their employability thereafter. It will consolidate and build on students’ learning in year 1.

This module is split into two components; Communication and Study Skills (CSS) and Quantitative Skills (QS)

Communication and Study Skills Syllabus (CSS)

Cycle 1
Scientific Writing:
Academic Integrity
Literature searching and referencing,
Writing different types of scientific writing and Journal Club discussion of a scientific paper.

Cycle 2
Job Application:
Development of a targeted CV and cover letter
Mock job interview.

First compulsory one to one meeting with academic advisor to discuss progress and development.

Cycle 3 Scientific report writing and experimental design: Writing a scientific report, understanding of experimental design and the basis for statistical analysis. Group discussions about ethics and ethical approval.
Cycle 4 Science Communication: Different types of science communication. Use of lay language in science communication. Designing and giving presentations. Verbal presentations based on scientific report.

Second compulsory one to one meeting with academic advisor to discuss progress and development.

Cycle 5
Quantitative Skills (QS) Syllabus

Students undertake weekly workshops on the following topics:
Data visualisation
t-tests
ANOVA
Chi-square
Linear regression and correlation
Non-linear regression

Students are then provided with data relating to their programme which they analyse as a group and complete a poster presentation during a conference format in week 8. The SAQ exam will be delivered online in week 12.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: Lectures to introduce key topics
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: 6 lectures on Communication and Study Skills and 12 lectures on quantitative skills. This refers to timetabled lectures.

Teaching Method 2 - Tutorial
Description: Tutorials with Academic Advisor
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: This refers to small group (5-7 students) tutorials with a designated member of academic staff. It includes staff directed group discussions about journal articles, an assessed verbal presentation, assessed mock interview and two compulsory one-to-one meetings with academic advisor to discuss progress and development.

Teaching Method 3 - Workshop
Description: Computer workshops
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: 11 x 2 h computer workshops

Across the module there will be a mix of asynchronous and synchronous content. Online asynchronous for the introductory lectures and Online synchronous for the group tutorials. Students will also have atleast two 1 hour seminars delivered in-person with a seminar tutor in socially distanced groups each semester.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1 (223) - SAQ online exam
Assessment 2 (223.1): Poster online session. Group mark assigned.
Assessment 3 (223.2) - Communication skills portfolio, including written assignments (written science communication, scientific report) and other assignments such as presentation and mock interview . Half of these assessments take place in semester 1, the other half in semester 2.

The module mark is an aggregated mark from all three assessments.
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Notes
Thanks for your feedback on the proposed changes. This module will undergo a full review this year for 2021-22 and is likely to be split into separate components similiar to our Year 1 essential skills module. The quantitative skills component within the module has recently undergone a full review for 2019-20. Therefore we have reviewed and reorganised the Communication and Study Skills (CSS) syllabus. We have changed the order of the study cycles to avoid assessment clashes with other modules in Year 2 in response to student feedback.

There have been no changes to the assessments but based on your feedback we have reviewed the learning outcomes, skills and syllabus.

We have added in a description of the QS syllabus into the syllabus section. This is split into CSS and QS.

We have reduced both the number of learning outcomes and also simplified some learning outcomes. We have also created some learning, research and employability outcomes to reflect the employability skills developed in the module. These new LOs, Skills and LREs have been mapped to the appropriate assessments.

More specificaly to address your comments about LOs and Skills;

LO4 (now renamed LO2) is explicitly linked to the Qs group assignment and so is covered in the QS component of the module. This has been made clearer in the syllabus. The students will also use these skills in the scientific report part of the CSS tasks.

The inclusion of Skill 3 (Now renamed S2)(group work) in the CSS component was a mistake and has now been removed. Skill 2 (group work) is linked to the group poster assignment for QS.

This module is due to commence in October 2019.

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Use a range of mathematical and numerical skills relevant to all biologists to summarise and interpret real-world data using graphs and tables.​​
 LO2 Develop and test hypotheses within the context of experimental design and within a range of biological fields, select appropriate quantitative methods to answer questions;​
 LO3 To develop programming skills relevant for statistical analysis and apply appropriate statistical and other analysis packages to analyse data;
​
 LO4 ​Recognise the moral and ethical issues of scientific investigations and discuss ethical standards and professional codes of conduct. ​​
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 ​Communication, listening and questioning and respecting others by contributing to discussions.
 S2 ​Team (group) working respecting others, co-operating, negotiating / persuading, awareness of interdependence with others
 S3 ​Independent working and readiness to improve own performance based on feedback/reflective learning.
 S4 ​Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.
Learning, Research and Employability
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LRE1 ​Structure and communicate ideas effectively, both orally and in writing;
 LRE2 Discuss and appropriately use relevant literature
 LRE3 Time management

Rationale
Removed Rob Beynon from teaching staff, as per his request.
Blurb
Overview
This module will continue, extend, and broaden the transferable skills developed in Year 1. It will focus on improving the students’ analytical, communication, quantitative, and employability skills. The communication skills component is assessed through a portfolio whereas the quantitative skills component is assessed through a group poster and SAQ.
Educational Aims
Enhance the development of the essential life science skills that students will require to improve their study skills;

Enable students to analyse and interpret scientific data and communicate results; ​

Enhance the employability prospects of students and career awareness. ​
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will continue, extend, and broaden the transferable skills developed in Year 1. It will focus on improving the students’ analytical, communication, quantitative, and employability skills. The communication skills component is assessed through a portfolio whereas the quantitative skills component is assessed through a group poster and SAQ.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus will focus on the development of a number of skills that will support students’ learning throughout their BSc or MBiolSci programme, and will contribute to their employability thereafter. It will consolidate and build on students’ learning in year 1.

This module is split into two components; Communication and Study Skills (CSS) and Quantitative Skills (QS)

Communication and Study Skills Syllabus (CSS)

Cycle 1
Scientific Writing:
Academic Integrity
Literature searching and referencing,
Writing different types of scientific writing and Journal Club discussion of a scientific paper.

Cycle 2
Job Application:
Development of a targeted CV and cover letter
Mock job interview.

First compulsory one to one meeting with academic advisor to discuss progress and development.

Cycle 3 Scientific report writing and experimental design: Writing a scientific report, understanding of experimental design and the basis for statistical analysis. Group discussions about ethics and ethical approval.
Cycle 4 Science Communication: Different types of science communication. Use of lay language in science communication. Designing and giving presentations. Verbal presentations based on scientific report.

Second compulsory one to one meeting with academic advisor to discuss progress and development.

Cycle 5
Quantitative Skills (QS) Syllabus

Students undertake weekly workshops on the following topics:
Data visualisation
t-tests
ANOVA
Chi-square
Linear regression and correlation
Non-linear regression

Students are then provided with data relating to their programme which they analyse as a group and complete a poster presentation during a conference format in week 8. The SAQ exam will be delivered online in week 12.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: Lectures to introduce key topics
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: 6 lectures on Communication and Study Skills and 12 lectures on quantitative skills. This refers to timetabled lectures.

Teaching Method 2 - Tutorial
Description: Tutorials with Academic Advisor
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: This refers to small group (5-7 students) tutorials with a designated member of academic staff. It includes staff directed group discussions about journal articles, an assessed verbal presentation, assessed mock interview and two compulsory one-to-one meetings with academic advisor to discuss progress and development.

Teaching Method 3 - Workshop
Description: Computer workshops
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: 11 x 2 h computer workshops

Across the module there will be a mix of asynchronous and synchronous content. Online asynchronous for the introductory lectures and Online synchronous for the group tutorials. Students will also have atleast two 1 hour seminars delivered in-person with a seminar tutor in socially distanced groups each semester.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1 (223) - SAQ online exam
Assessment 2 (223.1): Poster online session. Group mark assigned.
Assessment 3 (223.2) - Communication skills portfolio, including written assignments (written science communication, scientific report) and other assignments such as presentation and mock interview . Half of these assessments take place in semester 1, the other half in semester 2.

The module mark is an aggregated mark from all three assessments.
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Notes
Thanks for your feedback on the proposed changes. This module will undergo a full review this year for 2021-22 and is likely to be split into separate components similiar to our Year 1 essential skills module. The quantitative skills component within the module has recently undergone a full review for 2019-20. Therefore we have reviewed and reorganised the Communication and Study Skills (CSS) syllabus. We have changed the order of the study cycles to avoid assessment clashes with other modules in Year 2 in response to student feedback.

There have been no changes to the assessments but based on your feedback we have reviewed the learning outcomes, skills and syllabus.

We have added in a description of the QS syllabus into the syllabus section. This is split into CSS and QS.

We have reduced both the number of learning outcomes and also simplified some learning outcomes. We have also created some learning, research and employability outcomes to reflect the employability skills developed in the module. These new LOs, Skills and LREs have been mapped to the appropriate assessments.

More specificaly to address your comments about LOs and Skills;

LO4 (now renamed LO2) is explicitly linked to the Qs group assignment and so is covered in the QS component of the module. This has been made clearer in the syllabus. The students will also use these skills in the scientific report part of the CSS tasks.

The inclusion of Skill 3 (Now renamed S2)(group work) in the CSS component was a mistake and has now been removed. Skill 2 (group work) is linked to the group poster assignment for QS.

This module is due to commence in October 2019.

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Use a range of mathematical and numerical skills relevant to all biologists to summarise and interpret real-world data using graphs and tables.​​
 LO2 Develop and test hypotheses within the context of experimental design and within a range of biological fields, select appropriate quantitative methods to answer questions;​
 LO3 To develop programming skills relevant for statistical analysis and apply appropriate statistical and other analysis packages to analyse data;
​
 LO4 ​Recognise the moral and ethical issues of scientific investigations and discuss ethical standards and professional codes of conduct. ​​
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 ​Communication, listening and questioning and respecting others by contributing to discussions.
 S2 ​Team (group) working respecting others, co-operating, negotiating / persuading, awareness of interdependence with others
 S3 ​Independent working and readiness to improve own performance based on feedback/reflective learning.
 S4 ​Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.
Learning, Research and Employability
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LRE1 ​Structure and communicate ideas effectively, both orally and in writing;
 LRE2 Discuss and appropriately use relevant literature
 LRE3 Time management

Rationale
Removed Rob Beynon from teaching staff, as per his request.
Blurb
Overview
This module will continue, extend, and broaden the transferable skills developed in Year 1. It will focus on improving the students’ analytical, communication, quantitative, and employability skills. The communication skills component is assessed through a portfolio whereas the quantitative skills component is assessed through a group poster and SAQ.
Educational Aims
Enhance the development of the essential life science skills that students will require to improve their study skills;

Enable students to analyse and interpret scientific data and communicate results; ​

Enhance the employability prospects of students and career awareness. ​
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will continue, extend, and broaden the transferable skills developed in Year 1. It will focus on improving the students’ analytical, communication, quantitative, and employability skills. The communication skills component is assessed through a portfolio whereas the quantitative skills component is assessed through a group poster and SAQ.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus will focus on the development of a number of skills that will support students’ learning throughout their BSc or MBiolSci programme, and will contribute to their employability thereafter. It will consolidate and build on students’ learning in year 1.

This module is split into two components; Communication and Study Skills (CSS) and Quantitative Skills (QS)

Communication and Study Skills Syllabus (CSS)

Cycle 1
Scientific Writing:
Academic Integrity
Literature searching and referencing,
Writing different types of scientific writing and Journal Club discussion of a scientific paper.

Cycle 2
Job Application:
Development of a targeted CV and cover letter
Mock job interview.

First compulsory one to one meeting with academic advisor to discuss progress and development.

Cycle 3 Scientific report writing and experimental design: Writing a scientific report, understanding of experimental design and the basis for statistical analysis. Group discussions about ethics and ethical approval.
Cycle 4 Science Communication: Different types of science communication. Use of lay language in science communication. Designing and giving presentations. Verbal presentations based on scientific report.

Second compulsory one to one meeting with academic advisor to discuss progress and development.

Cycle 5
Quantitative Skills (QS) Syllabus

Students undertake weekly workshops on the following topics:
Data visualisation
t-tests
ANOVA
Chi-square
Linear regression and correlation
Non-linear regression

Students are then provided with data relating to their programme which they analyse as a group and complete a poster presentation during a conference format in week 8. The SAQ exam will be delivered online in week 12.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: Lectures to introduce key topics
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: 6 lectures on Communication and Study Skills and 12 lectures on quantitative skills. This refers to timetabled lectures.

Teaching Method 2 - Tutorial
Description: Tutorials with Academic Advisor
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: This refers to small group (5-7 students) tutorials with a designated member of academic staff. It includes staff directed group discussions about journal articles, an assessed verbal presentation, assessed mock interview and two compulsory one-to-one meetings with academic advisor to discuss progress and development.

Teaching Method 3 - Workshop
Description: Computer workshops
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: 11 x 2 h computer workshops

Across the module there will be a mix of asynchronous and synchronous content. Online asynchronous for the introductory lectures and Online synchronous for the group tutorials. Students will also have atleast two 1 hour seminars delivered in-person with a seminar tutor in socially distanced groups each semester.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1 (223) - SAQ online exam
Assessment 2 (223.1): Poster online session. Group mark assigned.
Assessment 3 (223.2) - Communication skills portfolio, including written assignments (written science communication, scientific report) and other assignments such as presentation and mock interview . Half of these assessments take place in semester 1, the other half in semester 2.

The module mark is an aggregated mark from all three assessments.

Notes
Thanks for your feedback on the proposed changes. This module will undergo a full review this year for 2021-22 and is likely to be split into separate components similiar to our Year 1 essential skills module. The quantitative skills component within the module has recently undergone a full review for 2019-20. Therefore we have reviewed and reorganised the Communication and Study Skills (CSS) syllabus. We have changed the order of the study cycles to avoid assessment clashes with other modules in Year 2 in response to student feedback.

There have been no changes to the assessments but based on your feedback we have reviewed the learning outcomes, skills and syllabus.

We have added in a description of the QS syllabus into the syllabus section. This is split into CSS and QS.

We have reduced both the number of learning outcomes and also simplified some learning outcomes. We have also created some learning, research and employability outcomes to reflect the employability skills developed in the module. These new LOs, Skills and LREs have been mapped to the appropriate assessments.

More specificaly to address your comments about LOs and Skills;

LO4 (now renamed LO2) is explicitly linked to the Qs group assignment and so is covered in the QS component of the module. This has been made clearer in the syllabus. The students will also use these skills in the scientific report part of the CSS tasks.

The inclusion of Skill 3 (Now renamed S2)(group work) in the CSS component was a mistake and has now been removed. Skill 2 (group work) is linked to the group poster assignment for QS.

This module is due to commence in October 2019.

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Use a range of mathematical and numerical skills relevant to all biologists to summarise and interpret real-world data using graphs and tables.​​
 LO2 Develop and test hypotheses within the context of experimental design and within a range of biological fields, select appropriate quantitative methods to answer questions;​
 LO3 To develop programming skills relevant for statistical analysis and apply appropriate statistical and other analysis packages to analyse data;
​
 LO4 ​Recognise the moral and ethical issues of scientific investigations and discuss ethical standards and professional codes of conduct. ​​
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 ​Communication, listening and questioning and respecting others by contributing to discussions.
 S2 ​Team (group) working respecting others, co-operating, negotiating / persuading, awareness of interdependence with others
 S3 ​Independent working and readiness to improve own performance based on feedback/reflective learning.
 S4 ​Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.
Learning, Research and Employability
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LRE1 ​Structure and communicate ideas effectively, both orally and in writing;
 LRE2 Discuss and appropriately use relevant literature
 LRE3 Time management
